head.title: AgroGP – Stopping Wildfires in El Pao, Venezuela
head.description: Planting, protecting, and educating to break the cycle of destruction. Your support drives real, community-led solutions.

hero.title: Plant, Protect, Educate:
hero.titleSpan: Stop the Fires in El Pao
hero.lead: A three-part mission to break the cycle of destruction: Reforest the land, Equip firefighters, Educate the next generation. Every dollar creates tangible impact.

about.title: Our Story of Hope
about.paragraph1: For decades, a devastating cycle has repeated in the savannas of Pao Municipality, Cojedes. Annual cultural burns spiral out of control, turning over 40,000 hectares into an inferno. The result? Irreparable damage to unique ecosystems, fauna on the brink of extinction, toxic smoke choking communities, and carbon emissions fueling the global climate crisis. The land lies barren.
about.paragraph2: But amid the ashes, there is a plan for hope. We launch the "Plant, Protect, Educate" initiative – a concrete three-pillar plan, developed together with local communities, firefighters, and schools, to break this cycle once and for all.
about.paragraph3: Your contribution is crucial and decisive. It's the piece missing to transform this plan into tangible action. Your contribution will make it possible to carry out each phase of this comprehensive intervention, from planting new green areas to equipping brigades and educating new generations.
about.paragraph4: With your support, you won't just finance a project; you'll be the catalyst for permanent change. Let's join efforts in recovering our savannas, protecting its biodiversity, and building a sustainable global future.

impactMap.title: Transforming Cojedes region, the heart of Venezuelan savanna
impactMap.impactCardDescription: In Cojedes, from 2001 to 2024, an average of 550 ktCO₂e per year was produced in areas where the main causes of forest cover loss caused deforestation.

impactCard.title: Impact in Cojedes
impactCard.description: In 2020, Cojedes had 530 kha of natural forest, which extended over 37% of its land surface. In 2024, it lost 560 kha of natural forest, equivalent to 270 kt of CO₂ emissions.
